issue.title: Move the construction of `LightingInput` in `apply_pbr_lighting` into its own function.

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: C-Code-Quality
labels.description: A section of code that is hard to understand or change

labels.name: S-Needs-Benchmarking
labels.description: This set of changes needs performance benchmarking to double-check that they help

labels.name: S-Needs-Review
labels.description: Needs reviewer attention (from anyone!) to move forward

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective
Reduce duplication in the `bevy_pbr` shaders by using a function to create `LightingInput` from `PbrInput` which can then be shared between `apply_pbr_lighting` and `ssr::fragment`.

## Solution
I created a function `pbr_input_to_lighting_input` in `pbr_lighting` to do this (lighting seemed the most logical place for it as that is where `LightingInput` lives and in a higher level language this would be a constructor). This also required moving `calculate_F0` and `calculate_diffuse_color` into `pbr_lighting` to prevent a circular dependency (infinite load during shader compilation), this makes sense for `calculate_F0` as this is now the only thing that uses it but `calculate_diffuse_color` does still have another user file.

## Questions for reviewers

- Should `pbr_input_to_lighting_input` instead accept a `ptr` to `PbrInput`, I don't feel like I have a sufficient grasp of shader optimisers to know whether this is better (or if we can trust this should always be inlined)?
- Should it instead live in `pbr_functions` which has the advantage of making this a non-breaking change (because no functions would have to move) but separates a constructor from its struct definition?

## Testing

I ran `ssr` and `anisotropy` and checked them for visual issues/crashes and ran as much CI as I could before running out of disk space. I tried to test `clearcoat` but that example is broken for me (#18104)

## Migration Guide

Shader function changes:
  - `calculate_diffuse_color` and `calculate_F0` have been moved from `bevy_pbr::pbr_functions` to `bevy_pbr::lighting`.

https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/blob/301f61845a26107ab36f83d2702f471642be25b1/crates/bevy_gltf/src/loader/gltf_ext/material.rs#L109-L123
Actually, this shouldn't matter as the only GlTF is the golf ball, the others are a `Sphere` with a material

removing these `ifdef`s works

https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/blob/301f61845a26107ab36f83d2702f471642be25b1/crates/bevy_pbr/src/render/pbr_bindings.wgsl#L20-L39

the bindless material is putting things on the wrong place if the features are disabled

my understading of what is happening is this,

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/78279006-307f-4c1b-a03e-7d27da872ee5)

the uniform has 16 binding but `9..=12` are behind a `cfg`, for bindful there is no issue since you access the items with bindings over 12 with `@group(n) @binding(13)`, but for bindless the items are completely removed from the struct on the shader and on the cpu side they are still pushed to the buffer as if the were the correct binding, e.g. you have on the cpu the data on `buffer[13]` and on the shader it try accessing it as `buffer[9]` which is complete garbage

i.e. the current macro does not treat gaps on the bindings for bindless
weird that this just happens of linux though
It happens on windows too. And yes, I came to the same conclusion, bindless mode is not handling gaps due to cargo features correctly.
i was taking from the results of the bevy example runner, which only shows flakiness on this example on linux
it's possible the software renderer on windows in CI doesn't support bindless, and this issue only happens when bindless is enabled

issue.title: Make the `StandardMaterial` bindless index table have a fixed size regardless of the features that are enabled.

labels.name: A-Rendering
labels.description: Drawing game state to the screen

labels.name: S-Ready-For-Final-Review
labels.description: This PR has been approved by the community. It's ready for a maintainer to consider merging it

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
Due to the preprocessor usage in the shader, different combinations of features could cause the fields of `StandardMaterialBindings` to shift around. In certain cases, this could cause them to not line up with the bindings specified in `StandardMaterial`. This resulted in #18104.

This commit fixes the issue by making `StandardMaterialBindings` have a fixed size. On the CPU side, it uses the `#[bindless(index_table(range(M..N)))]` feature I added to `AsBindGroup` in #18025 to do so. Thus this patch has a dependency on #18025.

Closes #18104.
